profileText: (Father of Charles Foster Bass), a Representative from New Hampshire; born in East Walpole, Norfolk County, Mass., October 6, 1912; graduated from Dartmouth College, Hanover, N.H., in 1934 and from Harvard Law School in 1938; was admitted to the New Hampshire bar in 1938 and commenced the practice of law in Manchester, N.H.; law clerk to Judge Woodbury of First Circuit Court of Appeals in 1941 and 1942; entered military service April 9, 1942, and served as air combat intelligence officer with General Chennault's Fourteenth Air Force in China from 1943 until discharged with rank of major in 1945; awarded the Bronze Star Medal and from the Nationalist Government of China received the Yun-Ma Medal for distinguished and meritorious service; resumed practice of law in Manchester and Peterborough, N.H.; member of the New Hampshire house of representatives 1939, 1941, 1947, and 1951; served in the State senate 1949-1951 as president; director and member of the executive committee of Bird & Son, Inc., East Walpole, Mass., 1948-1984; elected as a Republican to the Eighty-fourth and to the three succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1955-January 3, 1963); was not a candidate for renomination in 1962 to the Eighty-eighth Congress but was an unsuccessful candidate for the United States Senate; Republican National Committeeman from New Hampshire, 1964-1968; selectman of Peterborough, N.H., 1972-1976; died on October 25, 2011, in Peterborough, N.H.

researchRecord.name: 1935-1962, 69 feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Perkins Bass contain correspondence, speeches, press releases, scrapbooks, photos, tapes, films, memorabilia, and other papers, relating to Perkins Bass's career as a New Hampshire state legislator and U.S. representative, and to his activities in local, county, and State politics in New Hampshire. Includes congressional correspondence relating to postmasterships, job applications, and service academy appointments, and legislation and committee files; financial records and other files of Perkins Bass's campaign committees; and correspondence relating to Sherman Adams's campaign for the governorship. Correspondents include Sherman Adams, Ezra Taft Benson, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Richard Nixon, Lawrence O'Brien, Fred Seaton, and members of the White House staff. A finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: 1952-1977, 1 cubic foot.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Perkins Bass consist of correspondence, campaign information, press releases, newspaper clippings, speeches related to his political career and support of the Republican party. A finding aid is available in the library.

researchRecord.name: 1962-1972, 2 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Perkins Bass contain correspondence, press releases, poll studies, news clippings, and rosters. Includes correspondence with Eugene Cowen, president of United Public Relations Incorporated. Also includes some campaign materials. An unpublished guide is available in the library.

researchRecord.name: In the J. Duane Squires Papers, 1950-1964, 3 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include Perkins Bass. An inventory is available in the repository and online.
